704229f-a.title: Bronx: Pelham Bay Park - Joshua Pell Mansion.
704229f-a.text:
Pelham Bay Park (Bronx): A view of the Joshua Pell Mansion, one of the Pell houses, also known as the Collins House, dating back to pre-Revelutionary days. It is situated on the east side of Prospect Avenue (also known as the Split Rock Road), midway between the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad tracks and the city line of Pelham, Westchester County. Another Pell Mansion, said to be the most imposing of all, is located on the west side of Wolf's Lane, at Iden Avenue, on the Isaac Rodman property (1910 map),
in Pelham, Westchester County.
1891
Gift of Urbrock Collection
704229f-a.folder: Pelham Bay Park & Joshua Pell Mansion., Bronx, NY

701607f-a.title: Bronx: Pelham Bay Park - former Huntington Estate (caretaker's house).
701607f-a.text:
Pelham Bay Park: A view of the caretaker's dwelling on the former Collis P. Huntington estate. Between 1913 and 1927, according to G.W. Bromley's maps of those years, the estate was incorporated in Pelham Bay Park and constitutes the southeasternmost corner of the park, On the west shore of Eastchester Bay. That area is now (1937) occupied
by the Isaac L. Rice Playfield.
July 17, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
701607f-a.folder: Pelham Bay Park & former Huntington Estate (caretaker's house)., Bronx, NY

701605f-a.title: Bronx: Pelham Bay Park - Glover's Rock.
701605f-a.text:
7 - GLOVER'S ROCK, Pelham Bay Park. The tablet on this immense bowlder tells the story:-
"In Memory of the 550 Patriots, who, led by Colonel John Glover, held General Howe's army in check at the Battle of Pell's Point, October 18, 1776, thus aiding General Washington in his retreat to White Plains." After passing Glover's Rock with his army, Howe lunched under the branches of the Lord Howe Chestnut, already, described, No.4.
701605f-a.folder: Pelham Bay Park & Glover's Rock., Bronx, NY
